LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonBW.label: porcelain loong
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonBW.description: The centerpiece of a porcelain loong's genetic sequence.\n\nA spectrum of growth regulation genes exists in loong's cells. These genes are responsible for their monosex colonies and the complete inheritance of mother's genes among loong offsprings. As a result of loong's continued evolution these genes has stablized and any conflicting genes will be disabled.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonCB.label: pureblood loong
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonCB.description: The centerpiece of a pureblood loong's genetic sequence.\n\nA spectrum of growth regulation genes exists in loong's cells. These genes are responsible for their monosex colonies and the complete inheritance of mother's genes among loong offsprings. As a result of loong's continued evolution these genes has stablized and any conflicting genes will be disabled.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonGhoul.label: ghouloong
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonGhoul.description: The hidden gene activated when a loong was ghoulfied.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornBW.label: azure horns
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornBW.description: The ceramic-like textured horns unique to porcelain loongs. Due to the low genetic variety of porcelain loongs, no other varieties are found.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornCB.label: green horns
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornCB.description: The horns of pureblood loongs. There're many varieties of horns amid the purebloods, to name a few, the glassy horns with a trace of yellow in a green horn, glorious pearl horns, and there're a so-called ginger horn but don't you dare say that to a loong.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornPC.label: crimson horns
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornPC.description: The horns of papercut loongs. They're beautiful and decorated with subtle patterns, but there aren't a lot of varieties.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornWJ.label: jade horns
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonHornWJ.description: The horns of white jade loongs. They have an icy, slippery texture akin to that of jade.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonMilk.label: ambergris excrement
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonMilk.description: The customarily misnamed "ambergris" is actually the excrement of adult loongs. They are said to produce a special aroma and is a treasured food ingredient.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonPC.label: papercut loong
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonPC.description: The centerpiece of a papercut loong's genetic sequence.\n\nA spectrum of growth regulation genes exists in loong's cells. These genes are responsible for their monosex colonies and the complete inheritance of mother's genes among loong offsprings. As a result of loong's continued evolution these genes has stablized and any conflicting genes will be disabled.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailBW.label: azure tail
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailBW.description: The tail of porcelain loongs. They're miraculously soft but hard, and chilly to touch. It might be a good idea to sleep during the summer with one of this between your arms.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailCB.label: green tail
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailCB.description: The thick and muscular tail of a pureblood loong. Strong enough to break a few bones if it hits somebody.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailPC.label: crimson tail
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailPC.description: The red tail of a papercut loong. A membrane structure extends from the tail, which is artificially tailored. It was said there're tail barbers that styles them.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailWJ.label: jade tail
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonTailWJ.description: The tail of a white jade loong. Similar to that of a pureblood, but white in color.
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonWJ.label: jade loong
LanguageData.NY_gene_ForgingDragonWJ.description: The centerpiece of a white jade loong's genetic sequence.\n\nA spectrum of growth regulation genes exists in loong's cells. These genes are responsible for their monosex colonies and the complete inheritance of mother's genes among loong offsprings. As a result of loong's continued evolution these genes has stablized and any conflicting genes will be disabled.
LanguageData.NY_gene_LoongFireResistant.label: fireproof scales
LanguageData.NY_gene_LoongFireResistant.description: Fine transparent scales covered the skin of a pureblood loong. They're not flammable and highly resistant to heat, protecting a pureblood from fire.
